body_html:
I suspect the issue is that I'm behind a corporate firewall, which does "interesting" things with https, I get hit with this problem, under various guises, regularly.

At first, it looked to me like the issue was that the Python 2.7 license filename had changed from license.txt to license.rst.txt, and the file hash was wrong. For more explanation, see my earlier comment, which I've expanded up to explain this aspect of workaround. It seems to me you're saying the Python 2.7 license file isn't an issue for you. I still don't understand why!

If you don't see any issue, then this bug should be resolved. Still, I imagine other people, building Tensorflow behind other "interesting" corporate firewalls, will hit the same kind of issue. If so, my workaround may prove useful for them.

body:
I suspect the issue is that I'm behind a corporate firewall, which does "interesting" things with https, I get hit with this problem, under various guises, regularly.

At first, it looked to me like the issue was that the Python 2.7 license filename had changed from license.txt to license.rst.txt, and the file hash was wrong. For more explanation, see my earlier comment, which I've expanded up to explain this aspect of workaround. It seems to me you're saying the Python 2.7 license file isn't an issue for you. I still don't understand why!

If you don't see any issue, then this bug should be resolved. Still, I imagine other people, building Tensorflow behind other "interesting" corporate firewalls, will hit the same kind of issue. If so, my workaround may prove useful for them.
